A.Aberration: A departure from what is normal, usual, or expected

A.Abreast: Up to date with the latest news, ideas, or information

A.Abstain: Up to date with the latest news, ideas, or information

A.Abyss: A deep or seemingly bottomless chasm

A.Adept: A person who is skilled in a particular field

A.Agog: Very eager or curious to hear or see something

A.Allure: The quality of being powerfully and mysteriously attractive or fascinating

A.Altruism: The belief in or practice of selfless concern for the well-being of others

A.Arbiter: A person who decides the outcome of a dispute

A.Audacious: Showing a willingness to take surprisingly bold risks

A.Austere: Having an extremely plain and simple style or appearance

A.Abasement: The action or fact of abasing or being abased; humiliation or degradation

A.Accession: The action or process of formally joining an association or institution

A.Acerbic: Especially of a comment or style of speaking) sharp and forthright

A.Acolyte: A person who has become an adherent of a particular religion or faith

A.Acumen: The ability to make good judgments and quick decisions, typically in a particular domain

A.Apostle: A vigorous and pioneering advocate or supporter of a particular cause

A.Arson: The criminal act of deliberately setting fire to property

A.Abeyance: A state of temporary disuse or suspension

A.Abjure: Solemnly renounce (a belief, cause, or claim)

A.Anodyne: Not likely to cause offence or disagreement and somewhat dull

B.Blight: A thing that spoils or damages something

B.Blithe: Showing a casual and cheerful indifference considered to be callous or improper

B.Blowhard: A person who blusters and boasts in an unpleasant way

B.Burlesque: Noun, a variety show. Skit, farce, striptease

B.Barrage: A concentrated outpouring, as of questions or blows

B.Bucolic: (Adjective) Relating to the pleasant aspects of the countryside and country life

B.Bilk: Obtain or withhold money from (someone) by deceit or without justification

C.Cacophony: A harsh, discordant mixture of sounds

C.Confound: A concluding event, remark or section

C.Canonical: (Of an artist or work) belonging to the literary or artistic canon

C.Capricious: Given to sudden and unaccountable changes of mood or behavior

C.Chauvinism: Excessive or prejudiced loyalty or support for oneâ€™s own cause, group, or gender

C.Circumspect: Wary and unwilling to take risks

C.Coalesce: Come together and form one mass or whole

C.Coffer: The funds or financial reserves of a group or institution

C.Condone: Accept and allow (behavior that is considered morally wrong or offensive)

C.Contrite: Feeling or expressing remorse or penitence

C.Credulous: having or showing too great a readiness to believe things

C.Catharsis: The process of releasing and providing relief from strong or repressed emotions

C.Cloture: (In a legislative assembly) a procedure for ending a debate and taking a vote

C.Compendium: A collection of concise but detailed information about a particular subject

C.Coterie: A small group of people with shared interests or tastes

C.Cosset: Care for and protect in an overindulgent way

D.Deign: Do something that one considers to be beneath one's dignity

D.Docile: Ready to accept control or instruction; submissive

D.Demur: (Verb) Raise doubts or objections or show reluctance

D.Dictum: A short statement that expresses a general truth or principle

D.Daguerreotype: A picture that is reproduced in a different form

D.Dilettante: A person who cultivates an area of interest without real commitment or knowledge

D.Dyspeptic: Of or having indigestion or consequent irritability or

E.Endow: Provide with a quality, ability, or asset

E.Ephemeral: Lasting for a very short time

E.Ethos: The characteristic spirit of a culture, era, or community

E.Echelon: A level or rank in an organization, a profession, or society

E.Eddy: (Verb) (of water, air, or smoke) move in a circular way

E.Effigy: A sculpture or model of a person

E.Epithet: An adjective or descriptive phrase expressing a quality characteristic of the person or thing; a term of abuse

E.Errant: Erring or straying from the proper course or standards

E.Esoteric: Intended for or likely to be understood by only a small number of people with a specialized knowledge or interest

E.Egress: (Noun) The action of going out of or leaving a place

E.Ersatz: A substitute or substitute for something that is missing or not available

E.Erstwhile: Of or relating to the past

E.Euphony: The quality of being pleasing to the ear

F.Facetious: Treating serious issues with deliberately inappropriate humor

F.Falter: Move back and forth or waver

F.Fluke: Unlikely chance occurrence, especially a surprising piece of luck

F.Fringe: The unconventional, extreme, or marginal wing of a group or sphere of activity

F.Florid: Using unusual words or complicated rhetorical constructions

F.Foible: A minor weakness or eccentricity in someoneâ€™s character

F.Frenetic: Fast and energetic in a rather wild and uncontrolled way

F.Frieze: A broad horizontal band of sculpted or painted decoration, especially on a wall near the ceiling

F.Fusillade: A series of rapid and successive attacks
